summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) facilities manager at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York on August 4, 2021. The interview focuses on the malfunctioning camera system at the MCC on August 9-10, 2019, the period surrounding inmate Jeffrey Epstein's death, and the manager's knowledge and actions related to the camera failures.

events.title: Camera System Failure Discovered
events.description: Electronic technician allegedly discovers that multiple cameras and recorders in the MCC, particularly in the SHU (Special Housing Unit), are not recording. He claims to have notified a supervisor and was told to fix it the next day.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Inmate Jeffrey Epstein is found dead in his cell at the MCC. The official understanding is suicide by hanging/strangulation.

events.title: OIG Interview of BOP Facilities Manager
events.description: DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with the MCC facilities manager regarding the camera system failures and circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

events.title: Camera Project Initiated
events.description: A project to replace the MCC's outdated camera system was initiated, with a contract awarded and planning begun. The project was slow-moving and not yet implemented by August 2019.

locations: Metropolitan Correction Center (MCC), New York, New York
keyFacts: The camera recording system in the MCC's Special Housing Unit (SHU) largely failed on August 9-10, 2019, with only one camera (outside Ten South) potentially recording during the period surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The facilities manager witness was on vacation during the critical dates and has no direct memory of being notified about the camera failures by the technician ().
The camera system was described as old, antiquated, and prone to failure if two hard drives in a recorder failed. A project to replace it had been initiated in 2018 but was not completed.

Access to the physical camera recorders was controlled by the SIS office, and administrative access to the NICE software system was limited to comtechs like and possibly the computer services manager .
The witness stated the MCC was understaffed in the Comtech department at the time, with only one technician (), which he identified as a contributing factor to maintenance issues.
